input_text.Prompt:
Here's new tech that'll make wearables as non-invasive as a Band-Aid. Japanese researchers have created a printable conducive ink on cloth, which means your boxer briefs or sports bra could one day track your heart rate (among other things).

In an effort to make electronic wearables more, well, wearable, a team at the University of Tokyo developed the ink and announced it yesterday. In a single-step process, electrodes and wires can be printed on both surfaces of the textile using the wonder ink. This new super cloth is also way softer and stretchier than today's harder, more rigid wearables and printed electronics.Even when stretched to three times its length, the ink remained highly conducive.

This new material is somewhat similar to the conducive yarn teased at Google I/O this year, which Levi's is reportedly using to make your jeans a giant touchpad. The goal there is to swipe, pinch, tap, and drag your fingers across these smart threads to answer calls or turn off lights, just like you would on a mousepad or smartphone. (Read about our hands-on with this magic fabric here.)

Advertisement

The Tokyo researchers' ink, though, seems a lot stretchier and allows manufacturers to make wearables that'll be as skintight as fake tattoos. Yep, that's right. Tech tattoos.

The future is now.

[University of Tokyo via TechCrunch]

Generate a summary:
input_text.Response A: Starting in 2017, the South Korean military plan to develop robots that can detect and remove mine in the Demilitarised Zone (DMZ). The military plans to build 170 robots that can be put into operation by 2020, the budget for this project is estimated to be less than $431m. In addition, the Defence Acquisition Program Administration (DAPA) has said the military will also develop 100 unmanned vehicles for DMZ search operations in 2017.
input_text.Response B: University of Tokyo researchers have developed a new ink that can be printed on textiles in a single step to form highly conductive and stretchable connections, enabling sports garments to measure heart rate and muscle conditions. Currently, sensors are typically printed on fairly rigid surfaces, but these stretchy garments will be able to fit themselves to the human body. This ink is comprised of silver flakes, organic solvent, fluorine rubber and fluorine surfactant and ink exhibited high conductivity even when it was stretched to more than three times its original length.

label_annotations.factors_a: the response was a summary of a different subject matter about military and not clothing so the score was bad quality as a response.
label_annotations.factors_b: similar clothing response but did not have relevance really to the main topic.
